document.topic_text: Log In Sign Up Legal negligence and Australia's #climate targets A seminar organised by Australian-German Climate and Energy College and the Melbourne Law School with legal academic Tim Baxter presenting on 'Are Commonwealth climate targets legally negligent? An Australian Urgenda' John Englart EAM Embed The seminar notes advise: "The central claim, that the Commonwealth’s climate mitigation targets might form the basis of legally recognisable negligence, would be difficult to establish in Australian law. This seminar outlines the major hurdles to the legal claim’s success before contending that each may be surmountable. Despite considerable barriers, a claim in negligence against the Commonwealth government for insufficient action on climate change has a prospect of success." I'm at a @ClimateCollege law seminar: are Australia's #climate targets legally negligent? #aussieurgenda pic.twitter.com/w6qEMveNeT — John Englart EAM (@takvera) Mon, Aug 22 2016 02:59:56 Urgenda is the Dutch case whereby citizens from the Netherlands took their Government to court under the law of Tort and were successful in having a legal judgement handed down mandating that the Government needed to increase it's actions for 2020 targets. Here is my article when the judgement was handed down in June 2015. Dutch Court orders Netherlands Government cut CO2 emissions by 25 percent by 2020 | Climate Citizen A Dutch court in a landmark legal case has just handed down a verdict that the Netherlands Government has the legal duty to take measures against #climate change. Further, the court ordered that a 25% reduction of CO2 emissions, based on 1990 levels, must be accomplished by 2020 by the Dutch government in accordance with IPCC scientific recommendations for industrial countries. John Englart June 2015 was a busy month as a lawsuit by teenagers in Washington State was also successful with an interim injunction. While at Port Vila, Vanuatu, The Pacific Declaration for climate Justice signed by several Pacific Nations on June 8, 2015, threatened legal action to recover damages against major climate polluters .
